oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Prevalence and Distribution of Antimicrobial Resistance
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dargatz, David A.
Fedorka-Cray, Paula J.
Peterson, Kenneth E.
Hollinger, Kathy
Wineland, Nora E.
Tollefson, Linda
Ferris, Kathy
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: antimicrobial resistance
antimicrobial use practices
human health care
agricultural health care
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Concerns about antimicrobial resistance have grown in recent years, becoming a truly global issue today. In addition, the antimicrobial issue is not limited to either the agricultural or human health care arenas. The World Health Organization has seated several consultancy groups to discuss the implications of antimicrobial use and resistance development. The National Academy of Sciences also has taken up the issue of antimicrobial use and resistance. Numerous other groups have held public and private meetings to discuss various aspects of antimicrobial resistance. Though there is little consensus regarding the roles of various antimicrobial use practices in the development of resistance that can impact public health, there is widespread recognition that the issue merits further study. There is a sense of urgency in our need for more data and information.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 1999; 10-11
